content.transcript:
Although cleaning is intended to remove microbiological hazards, unsatisfactory cleaning may result in the redistribution of contamination, which may be an even greater hazard.

Other hazards include failure to destroy pathogens and failure to clean and disinfect cleaning equipment after use.

There can also be cross-contamination, especially from cloths. Separate, colour-coded or disposable cloths are preferred

Cleaning may also result in chemical contamination due to inappropriate use or storage of chemicals

A typical example of this is cleaning near open food.

Failure to rinse in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions may also result in chemical taint of food

Physical hazards like brush bristles may also occur from defective cleaning equipment or inappropriate cleaning equipment such as soft wooden handles.

page.bullet: Redistribution of contamination due to unsatifsactory cleaning
Failure to clean and disinfect cleaning equipment after use
Contamination due to inappropriate use or storage of chemicals
Contamination from defective cleaning equipment e.g. brush bristles
Inappropriate cleaning equipment, e.g. soft wooden handles.
